_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Monrovia Nursery has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Monrovia Nursery, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Monrovia Nursery has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name               | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)

West Recycle                 Chlorine                          4,000

East Recycle                 Chlorine                          4,000

River Pump                   Chlorine                          2,000

Chlorine Storage Yard        Chlorine                          22,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical p

roperty damage.

1. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

2. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

3. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices



Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Facility Layout



Monrovia Nursery operates a 600 acre nursery in Woodlake, CA. The facility has several chlorine systems that are used for the disinfection of irrigation water in order to protect plants from various pathogens. The chlorine is metered into water streams and distributed as chlorinated irrigation water at the following locations:

 

West Recycle

East Recylce

River Pump

 

Chlorine System Equipment

The processes operate as follows: ton containers are connected to the irrigation water disinfection process through process tubing and piping at the three (3) injection locations. Chlorine gas is withdrawn from the ton containers by a vacuum created by the flow of water from the water pump. This vacuum opens the vacuum regulator diaphragm and withdraws the chlorine gas from the ton containers at a controlled feed rate set by the operators with the use of the rate valve on the chlorinator. The gas is injected into the water feed line where it becomes a chlorine/water solution and is distributed to the various locations throughout the plant in need of irrigation water.  

 

 

Process Chemistry

At Monrovia Nursery chlorine gas (Cl2) is used for the disinfection of irrigation water in order to protect plants from various pathogens. The chlorine, when added to water, yields both chloric (HCl) and hypochlorous (HOCl) acid (see chemical equation below)

in aqueous solution. This combination is effective in killing bacteria, viruses, pathogens and other micro-organisms. Note that the equation below is easily reversible which results in "off-gassing" of chlorine gas from water that contains high concentrations of the acids.



Cl2 + H2O → HOCl + HCl



The chlorination process begins with the chlorine gas being drawn from the ton containers through a pressure reducing valve, reduced to a vacuum at a vacuum regulator valve mounted inside the chlorinator, metered through a manually-adjusted rate valve, and finally injected into water. 

 

Safety Systems



All ton containers are chocked or cradled and stored securely in the chlorine process areas. The chlorine process areas are fenced and locked at all times. 

Several safety features are built into the vacuum regulators used in the chlorination process at Monrovia Nursery. The regulator acts as a safety shut-off valve in the event that the vacuum is broken. A pressure relief vent has also been incorporated into the vacuum regulator to prevent pressure from building up in the system.

Each chlorine ton container at Monrovia Nursery is protected from overpressure with three (3) fusible plugs on each side of the container (6 total). The fusible plugs consist of a brass plug with a fusible metal insert that is designed to melt between 157?F-170?F.

Emergency eyewash and safety showers are located in various areas throughout the facility and can be used to decontaminate if chemical exposure occurs.

Fire extinguishers are located near the chlorine processes to assist in handling small fires that could occur during normal operation.

Wind socks are located near the chlorine processes. Employees have been instructed to consider the wind direction when evacuating during a chlorine release.

 

Process Classification

Each chlorine injection system at Monrovia Nursery consists of ton containers, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The Chlorine Sto

rage Yards consists of multiple ton containers. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the chlorine systems at Monrovia Nursery are treated as four (4) independent processes.



West Recycle - Two (2) ton containers

East Recycle - Two (2) ton containers

River Pump - One (1) ton container with the possibility of connecting a second ton container

Chlorine Storage Yard - Eleven (11) ton containers  



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of chlorine in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Monrovia Nursery has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the chlorine processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Chlorine



The chlorination process at Monrovia Nursery is an integral part of the overall business and operates year round. The chlorination process utilizes two ton containers at the West and East Recycling process areas and one ton container at the River Pump process area, with another eleven ton containers stored in the chlorine storage yard to be distributed to the processing areas as needed. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of a chlorine leak. 



Monrovia Nursery personnel monitor the chlorination process. In addition, the process is checked frequently during operation by our outside water treatment contractor. This contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our chlorine equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Monrovia Nursery has had no accidental release

within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Monrovia Nursery's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Monrovia Nursery has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Monrovia Nursery continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Monrovia Nursery's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Monrovia Nursery's management t

eam can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Monrovia Nursery has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Monrovia Nursery has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Monrovia Nursery now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Monrovia Nursery employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Monrovia Nursery will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
